update.description:
Major pull request including largescale implementation changes to the bases and operators.  Main feature changes that affect users are outlined below:

Additions:

* SinCos parity basis

* Nonlinear BVP solver

* Hilbert transform operator

* MPI Alltoallv-based distributed transposes

* Many parsing additions

    * Substitution rules for text-replacement

    * Fields as NCCs

    * Compound derivatives, i.e. "d(u, x=5)"

* Tolerance-based NCC expansions

Changes:

* Dropping the "2" from the package name

* Move default config file to package level

* Basis objects require names on instantiation

* Problem objects require domain on instantiation

* Solver objects are obtained from problem method, not by direct instantiation

Removals:

* No more sympy dependency: all parsing done though operator trees

* basis.grid-shaped arrays no longer allowed as NCCs.  Use fields instead.

Examples have been updated and extended.
update.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

content.raw:
I think there's a typo in the 3D RB docstring:  There should be no "plot" in this line:

mpiexec -n 4 python3 plot_2d_series.py plot snapshots/*.h5

Otherwise I think everything is working well, so I'll approve this PR!
content.html:
I think there's a typo in the 3D RB docstring: There should be no "plot" in this line:

mpiexec -n 4 python3 plot_2d_series.py plot snapshots/*.h5

Otherwise I think everything is working well, so I'll approve this PR!

content.raw:
To move this along quickly I've just changed the timestepper to SBDF2 and confirmed that it still runs fine with the current CFL settings, etc.  

Would be good to see a larger study later on, though.

content.raw:
I agree with Daniel.  I would be happy to test out a few of our solvers on this problem and write it up.

I'll do an initial test with RK443 and confirm what CFL works, then let's do the larger timestepper study as a later PR within the next week or two (completely swamped this week and don't want to hold up the PR).

I think this is a good chance and a good problem to do a time-stepper convergence study on, which I've been interested in doing for a while.
content.html:
I agree with Daniel. I would be happy to test out a few of our solvers on this problem and write it up.

I'll do an initial test with RK443 and confirm what CFL works, then let's do the larger timestepper study as a later PR within the next week or two (completely swamped this week and don't want to hold up the PR).

I think this is a good chance and a good problem to do a time-stepper convergence study on, which I've been interested in doing for a while.

pull_request.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

pullrequest.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

content.raw: I think on this problem, all the timesteppers are probably fairly equivalent.  However, when writing new problems I think people often modify existing example problems.  I did exactly this when I started running the fully compressible kelvin-helmholtz problem.  The issue with SBDF3 is that it's unstable when you try to implicitly step over things (in my case, sound waves).  So I think it might be safer for people experimenting with these scripts to have the default be a more robust timestepper.  Even SBDF2 is much better I think.
content.html: I think on this problem, all the timesteppers are probably fairly equivalent. However, when writing new problems I think people often modify existing example problems. I did exactly this when I started running the fully compressible kelvin-helmholtz problem. The issue with SBDF3 is that it's unstable when you try to implicitly step over things (in my case, sound waves). So I think it might be safer for people experimenting with these scripts to have the default be a more robust timestepper. Even SBDF2 is much better I think.

content.raw:
Fixed the seeds and removed the greek.  

I haven't done any thorough tests with the timesteppers on these problems, but if anyone goes through that it might make for a good page in the docs (i.e. just tracking which timesteppers we've found work better for which problems, with quantitative data on times-to-solution).
content.html:
Fixed the seeds and removed the greek.

I haven't done any thorough tests with the timesteppers on these problems, but if anyone goes through that it might make for a good page in the docs (i.e. just tracking which timesteppers we've found work better for which problems, with quantitative data on times-to-solution).

pullrequest.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

content.raw:
Added a couple helper functions comparing the dedalus and exact solutions.

It's best for the internal tests to use relative imports, so you can run tests on any local Dedalus package, not just the first one on the system python path.  This means, though, that you can't just execute the test modules from inside the package, but the python testing frameworks (like py.test) can properly collect them.  

Eventually I'll try to flesh this out into more of a proper testing framework, but likely not before the next big set of implementation changes for the bases.
content.html:
Added a couple helper functions comparing the dedalus and exact solutions.

It's best for the internal tests to use relative imports, so you can run tests on any local Dedalus package, not just the first one on the system python path. This means, though, that you can't just execute the test modules from inside the package, but the python testing frameworks (like py.test) can properly collect them.

Eventually I'll try to flesh this out into more of a proper testing framework, but likely not before the next big set of implementation changes for the bases.

pull_request.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

pullrequest.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

content.raw:
2d_rayleigh_benard: I suggest that we fix a random seed so that you always get the same simulation every time (same with 3D problem). Can we also switch to another timestepper that we like better? RK443?

3d_rayleigh_benard: Using greek letters is fun, but causes problems on some computers, so I think we should remove the epsilon.

Also, the example notebooks (i.e., the ones explaining bases, fields, operators, etc.) haven't been updated yet.  Are we waiting to update them after this PR?
content.html:
2d_rayleigh_benard: I suggest that we fix a random seed so that you always get the same simulation every time (same with 3D problem). Can we also switch to another timestepper that we like better? RK443?

3d_rayleigh_benard: Using greek letters is fun, but causes problems on some computers, so I think we should remove the epsilon.

Also, the example notebooks (i.e., the ones explaining bases, fields, operators, etc.) haven't been updated yet. Are we waiting to update them after this PR?

content.raw:
In poisson.py:

BVP -> LBVP

Also, I get an error on savefig:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "poisson.py", line 40, in <module>
    fig.savefig('poisson.png')
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'savefig'

If you try to print(fig) it returns None.
content.html:
In poisson.py:

BVP -> LBVP

Also, I get an error on savefig:

Traceback (most recent call last): File "poisson.py", line 40, in <module> fig.savefig('poisson.png') AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'savefig'

If you try to print(fig) it returns None.

pull_request.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

pullrequest.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

content.raw:
When I try to run the airy and/or bessel tests I get:

lecoanet$ python3 bessel.py 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "bessel.py", line 13, in <module>
    from ...public import *
SystemError: Parent module '' not loaded, cannot perform relative import

Also, it doesn't look to me like any comparison is actually done in these scripts -- maybe we should include something where it calculates the error and checks that the error is small?
content.html:
When I try to run the airy and/or bessel tests I get:

lecoanet$ python3 bessel.py Traceback (most recent call last): File "bessel.py", line 13, in <module> from ...public import * SystemError: Parent module '' not loaded, cannot perform relative import

Also, it doesn't look to me like any comparison is actually done in these scripts -- maybe we should include something where it calculates the error and checks that the error is small?

pull_request.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

pullrequest.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

content.raw:
I've tested this PR against Taylor-Couette growth rates, finding identical accuracy to the previous version. Also, I've confirmed that both my TC notebook and Daniel's KH notebook work properly. As soon as this PR is accepted, I'll post one including these notebooks.

I have one minor suggestion: perhaps the default log level could be set from DEBUG back to INFO. As of now, Dedalus produces a LOT of output, much of which is not always useful in everyday use.  Regardless, I'm approving the PR now. Great work, Keaton!
content.html:
I've tested this PR against Taylor-Couette growth rates, finding identical accuracy to the previous version. Also, I've confirmed that both my TC notebook and Daniel's KH notebook work properly. As soon as this PR is accepted, I'll post one including these notebooks.

I have one minor suggestion: perhaps the default log level could be set from DEBUG back to INFO. As of now, Dedalus produces a LOT of output, much of which is not always useful in everyday use. Regardless, I'm approving the PR now. Great work, Keaton!

update.description:
Major pull request including largescale implementation changes to the bases and operators.  Main feature changes that affect users are outlined below:

Additions:

* SinCos parity basis

* Nonlinear BVP solver

* Hilbert transform operator

* MPI Alltoallv-based distributed transposes

* Many parsing additions

    * Substitution rules for text-replacement

    * Fields as NCCs

    * Compound derivatives, i.e. "d(u, x=5)"

* Tolerance-based NCC expansions

Changes:

* Dropping the "2" from the package name

* Move default config file to package level

* Basis objects require names on instantiation

* Problem objects require domain on instantiation

* Solver objects are obtained from problem method, not by direct instantiation

Removals:

* No more sympy dependency: all parsing done though operator trees

* basis.grid-shaped arrays no longer allowed as NCCs.  Use fields instead.

Examples have been updated and extended.
update.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

pull_request.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

pullrequest.title: New parsing framework, drop the 2, parity basis

content.raw:
I've tested the new parser approach for NCC problems, especially stratified convection, fairly extensively.  The tolerance based NCC expansions are significantly simpler to use than our prior system.

The cythonized MPI alltoallv transpose approach is competitive with our FFTW transpose approach and scales well (2-D problems scale to the 2-pencils per core limit).
content.html:
I've tested the new parser approach for NCC problems, especially stratified convection, fairly extensively. The tolerance based NCC expansions are significantly simpler to use than our prior system.

The cythonized MPI alltoallv transpose approach is competitive with our FFTW transpose approach and scales well (2-D problems scale to the 2-pencils per core limit).
